title: 113_s1953
content:
The "Oversight Workforce Improvement Act of 2014" is the short title of this Act. It involves investigations, audits, inspections, evaluations, and reviews conducted by inspectors general. Section 3518(c) of title 44, United States Code is amended to exempt certain information collection activities from the subchapter. This includes evaluations, reviews, audits, investigations conducted by the Federal Accountability and Spending Transparency Board, Council of the Inspectors General on Integrity and Efficiency, and Office of Inspector General. Additionally, there is an exemption from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM DISCLOSURE UNDER FOIA.

Information related to an agency's information security program or practices is exempt from disclosure under FOIA if revealing it could lead to unauthorized access, use, or disruption of the information system. Agencies must segregate and disclose non-exempt information accordingly. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO THE INSPECTOR GENERAL ACT OF 1978 AND THE INSPECTOR GENERAL REFORM ACT OF 2008. Incorporation of provisions from the Inspector General Reform Act of 2008 into the Inspector General Act of 1978, regarding the classification and pay of Inspector Generals of designated Federal entities. The pay of an Inspector General shall be at or above that of senior level executives within the entity. The Inspector General Act of 1978 incorporates provisions from the Inspector General Reform Act of 2008, specifying the compensation of senior level executives within designated Federal entities. Repeal of Section 4(b) of the Inspector General Reform Act of 2008 and addition of a new section on pay retention are included in the amendments. The amendments include a new section on pay retention for senior level executives within designated Federal entities. The provisions of section 3392 of title 5, United States Code apply to career appointees of the Senior Executive Service appointed as Inspector General, ensuring no reduction in pay for Federal employees appointed to this position. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include provisions for allegations of wrongdoing against the special counsel or deputy special counsel. The term "Special Counsel" refers to the Special Counsel appointed under section 1211(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Integrity Committee has the authority to receive, review, and refer allegations of wrongdoing against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel, similar to the process for allegations against an Inspector General. The Special Counsel must recuse themselves from considering any allegations brought under this provision. The Integrity Committee has the authority to receive, review, and refer allegations of wrongdoing against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel. This paragraph clarifies that access to the Merit Systems Protection Board for review is not eliminated. If an allegation involves a specific section, failure to obtain corrective action within 120 days after the allegation is received by the Integrity Committee will be considered satisfactory for certain purposes. The Integrity Committee is also authorized to establish regulations. The Integrity Committee can establish regulations and rules as needed, with consultation requirements. Section 7(b) of the Inspector General Reform Act of 2008 is repealed. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is further amended to include Federal agencies and designated entities. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to include Federal agencies and designated entities, replacing "agency" with "Federal agency or designated Federal entity" throughout the text. Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the head and the Inspector General of each Federal agency and designated Federal entity must implement these changes. The General Act of 1978 and designated Federal entities must implement the amendments. Corrections include changing executive order numbers and punctuation in the Inspector General Act of 1978. The Inspector General Act of 1978 is amended to correct spelling errors, such as changing "subpena" to "subpoena" and updating references to sections within the Act. Section 744 of the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2009 is repealed. SEC. 5. INSPECTOR GENERAL OF THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY is amended to include the Inspectors General of the Intelligence Community and the Central Intelligence Agency.
